verses.verse: And right away, after the head priests took up the counsel in the morning with the older men, Old Testament transcribers, and the whole council, after tying Jesus up, they carried Him off and turned Him over to Pilate.
And Pilate asked Him, "Are you the king of the Jewish people?" When Jesus answered, He said to him, "You are saying it."
And the head priests were leveling many complaints against Him. But He answered nothing.
Pilate asked Him again, saying, "Are you answering nothing? Look at how many complaints they are witnessing against you."
But Jesus did not answer anything anymore in such a way for Pilate to be amazed.
At each festival he dismissed one prisoner to them, even whom they were requesting.
There was the prisoner called Barabbas who had been locked up with the rioters, some who had committed murder in the disturbance.
And after the crowd shouted out, it began to be asking him to do just as he was always doing for them.
Pilate answered them, saying, "Do you want that I dismiss the King of the Jewish people to you?"
You see, he knew that because of envy the head priests had turned Him in.
But the head priests riled up the crowd so that he might dismiss Barabbas to them instead.
When Pilate responded again, he said to them, "So what do you want that I should do to Him whom you say to be King of the Jewish people?"
The people again yelled, "Nail Him to a cross."
But Pilate was saying to them, "You see, what bad thing did He do?" But the people yelled much more, "Nail Him to a cross."
Pilate, intending to do the adequate thing for the crowd, dismissed Barabbas to them and turned Jesus over, after he beat Him with a whip, so that He might be nailed to a cross.
The soldiers led Him away inside the courtyard that is a Roman fort. And they call the whole regiment together,
put purple on Him, and place a thorny award wreath around Him that they wove together.
And they began to be greeting Him, "Welcome, King of the Jewish people."
And they were hitting His head with a stick, spitting at Him, and, as they placed their knees on the ground, bowing down to Him.
And when they mocked Him, they stripped the purple off Him and put the clothes, His own clothes, on Him. And they lead Him out so that they might nail Him to a cross.
And they sequester help from someone passing by, Simon, a Cyrenian, coming from a field, the father of Alexander and Rufus, so that he might pick up His cross.
And they carry Him on to the place, Golgotha, that is translated from Aramaic as "Place of a Skull."
And they were giving Him wine that had been mixed with perfume to drink, but Jesus did not take it.
And after they nailed Him to a cross, they were thoroughly dividing His clothes throwing dice on them to determine who would take what.
It was the third hour (9:00 a. m.), and they nailed Him to a cross.
And the inscription of His accusation that had been inscribed was, "The King of the Jewish people."
And together with Him, they nail two bandits on crosses, one at places to the right and one at places to the left of Him.
And the Old Testament writing was accomplished, the one that says, (in Isaiah 53:12) "And he was considered with criminals."
And the people traveling by were saying hurtful things about Him, shaking their heads and saying, "Wow, the One who tears the temple down and in three days builds it.
Rescue yourself and climb down off the cross."
Likewise, the head priests mocking to each other with the Old Testament transcribers were also saying, "Others He rescued, Himself He is not able to rescue.
The Anointed King, the king of Israel, must climb down now off the cross so that we might see and trust." Also the bandits that had been nailed on crosses together with Him were insulting Him.
When the sixth hour (noon) happened, darkness happened on the whole earth until the ninth hour (3:00 p. m.).

And at the hour, the ninth one (3:00 p. m.), Jesus shouted with a loud voice, saying, "Eloi, Eloi, lamma sabachthani," that is translated from Aramaic as "My God, My God, why did You leave Me down in here?"
And when some of the people that had stood nearby heard it, they were saying, "Look, He is hollering for Elijah."
When one person ran, filled a sponge full of sour wine, and put it around a stick, he was giving Him a drink, saying, "Leave Him alone, we will see if Elijah comes to take Him down."
But when Jesus left, He breathed out a loud sound.
And the curtain of the temple was split in two from top to bottom.
When the centurion (Latin for lieutenant), the one who had stood nearby facing Him, saw that after yelling He breathed out His last breath like this, he said, "This person truly was a son of a god."
There were also women watching off at a distance, among whom were also Mary (the Magdalene), Mary (the mother of little James and Joses), Salome,
(who also, when He was in Galilee, were following Him and serving Him), and many other women who walked up together with Him to Jerusalem.
And when it already became evening, since it was a preparation day (that is, the day before a Sabbath),
Joseph (the one from Arimathaea, a proper advisor who himself also was awaiting the empire of God) came, who was daring. He went in to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
Pilate was amazed if He had already died. And after he called for the centurion, he asked him if He died a long time ago.
And when he knew it from the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph for free.

And after purchasing linen cloth and taking Him down, he wrapped Him in the linen cloth and placed Him down in a burial vault that was one that had been chiseled from rock. And he rolled a stone over the door of the burial vault.
Mary (the Magdalene) and Mary (mother of Joses) were watching where He is placed.
